III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4125 Personal possessions; money; clothing;
Section storage space
Description (1) A licensee shall have a written policy that designates all of the
following:
(a) The method used to safeguard residents' personal
possessions and money.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff called a clear and left the bathroom door open. A youth went
in and destroyed another youth's personal stuff. Youth are having
their items lost and they are not being replaced.
Investigation Interviews:
Licensing Consultant was interviewed via phone on April 30,
2025. Licensing Consultant reported Youth A disclosed these
concerns during an interview she had with her. She reported
Youth A was upset when staff had called to clear the area, they
did not close Youth A’s bathroom which made it, so another youth
destroyed her personal items in the bathroom. Licensing
Consultant reported Youth A was upset because the facility did
not buy her new products.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 2,
2025. Youth A reported a couple of weeks ago Youth B went into
her bathroom and destroyed all of her Bath and Body Works
products. She reported Youth B became upset with Youth A and
wanted to destroy Youth A’s personal items. Youth A reported
staff never closed her bathroom door when Youth B was upset
which is how Youth B got into Youth A’s bathroom to destroy her
personal items. She reported that, during that time, Youth C
shared a bathroom with her. Youth A reported she could not
remember what date this occurred or which staff were working.
She reported Supervisor never replaced her items that were
damaged by Youth B. Youth A reported she had had other items
such as clothes, a jacket, and shoes that needed to be replaced
by the facility as well and they never followed through. She
reported she talked with Clinical Supervisor about those items
needing to be replaced which Clinical Supervisor stated she would
talk with Supervisor about getting them replaced. Youth A
reported when she spoke to Supervisor about getting her new
items, Supervisor told her she was not going to replace her items.
She reported she did get some new clothes but never received a
new jacket or shoes.
2

Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 2,
2025. Youth B was very emotional during her interview and did not
want to speak about the incident with Youth A. She denied any of
her personal items ever getting destroyed or lost. Youth B
reported that youth at the facility do get items replaced when
needed by staff. She reported when a youth is dysregulated staff
at the facility will call a clear to make sure the area is safe and
secure for that youth and the other youth. Youth B reported
sometimes staff will close open doors, but their main focus is to
keep that youth in crisis safe. She denied having any concerns
about staff not following proper protocol for a clear situation.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 2,
2025. Youth C reported she did share a bathroom with Youth A.
She confirmed Youth B did pour out Youth A’s Bath and Body
Works items in their bathroom. Youth C could not remember when
this happened or what staff were working on but knew Youth B
was mad at Youth A and that is why she did it. She reported she
believed Youth A did get replacement items from the facility for
what was destroyed. Youth C reported she does not have
concerns with the facility not keeping the youth’s personal items
safe or not replacing them when it is appropriate. She reported
that her personal items have never been destroyed. Youth C
reported she does not have concerns with staff not following the
protocol for clearing the unit when someone on the unit is upset.
She reported the staff’s main focus is the youth themselves to
make sure everyone is safe. Youth C reported sometimes staff will
close open doors during a clear call.
Clinical Supervisor was interviewed via phone on May 2,
2025. Clinical Supervisor reported Youth A has reported to her
concerns about clothing items which have been replaced. She
reported she was not involved in the concerns of Bath and Body
Works items that needed to be replaced. Clinical Supervisor
reported whenever a youth needs new items or personal items get
destroyed, the facility will replace them.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face virtually via Microsoft
TEAMS on May 13, 2025. Staff 1 reported working with Staff 2 on
April 20, 2025. He reported Youth B was upset with Youth A
because she heard Youth A talking on a phone. Staff 1 reported
Youth B wanted to assault Youth A physically, so to keep
everyone safe, it was decided Youth A would go to a different
wing of the facility. He reported he brought Youth A over, and
Youth B stayed with Staff 2. He reported he did check in with Staff
2, who reported Youth B was able to get into Youth A’s bathroom
3

and did damage to her Bath and Body Works items. He reported
this was told to Supervisor, and there was an incident report
documented. Staff 1 reported there was not a full clear code in
place because Youth A was willing to move over to the other wing
to give Youth B some space. He reported that it is best practice to
keep the bathroom doors all shut, but sometimes the youth do not
close them all the way. Staff 1 reported that all of Youth A’s items
were replaced.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face virtually via Microsoft
TEAMS on May 13, 2025. Staff 2 reported on April 20, 2025, that
Youth B had gotten upset with Youth A when Youth A was on a
phone call. He reported that Youth B was trying to physically fight
Youth A, but Staff 1 was able to get Youth A to go to another unit.
Staff 2 reported that he stayed with Youth B and tried to verbally
de-escalate her. He reported Youth B attempted to get into Youth
A’s bedroom but was unsuccessful. Staff 2 reported Youth B did
rip up Youth A’s phone contact list. He reported Youth A must
have left her bathroom door open, and Youth B did destroy her
Bath and Body Works products. Staff 2 reported this was reported
to Staff 1, who contacted the Supervisor about this. He reported
the next day that those items were replaced. Staff 2 reported the
facility will always replace the destroyed items for the youth. He
reported that during this situation, the two youth were separated,
and there was no other youth on the unit. Staff 2 reported he did
not notice Youth A’s bathroom door was cracked open because
his main focus was trying to verbally de-escalate Youth B.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on May
27, 2025. Supervisor reported she never told Youth A that her
personal items would not get replaced. She reported all of Youth
A’s items have been replaced.
Tour Observation:
A tour of the facility occurred on May 2, 2025. Youth A’s room
was viewed and there appeared to be many clothing items, shoes,
and other personal items located within her room. This consultant
also viewed Youth A’s personal bathroom which there were
multiple Bath and Body Work’s items within her bathroom that
appeared to be in use. Both Youth A’s bedroom and bathroom
doors were open.
Video Review
Video record of April 20, 2025 was reviewed by this
consultant on May 13, 2025- The video recording is within the
main milieu area where Youth B was pushing Staff 2 to try to get
4

to Youth A. Staff 1 opened the door to the other wing and Youth A
went to that side of the unit with Staff 1. Staff 2 stayed with Youth
B on the other wing where Youth B continued to try to get into
Youth A’s bedroom. Staff 2 maintained supervision of Youth B,
called for support, and never went hands-on with Youth B. The
video footage never showed Youth B going into Youth A’s
bedroom or bathroom.
Documents Reviewed:
- Email from Foster Care Worker dated May 1, 2025-
Foster Care Worker reported she was aware of Youth A
making a complaint about her bathroom door being left
open during a clear call on the unit and another youth
destroying her personal items. Foster Care Worker
reported that this matter happened several weeks if not
months ago. She reported as for as the facility losing Youth
A’s items, she is unaware of this, and Youth A never made
complaints about this prior.
- Facility incident report dated April 20, 2025 completed
by Staff 1- This incident report noted Youth B was upset
with Youth A after overhearing Youth A on a phone call.
Youth B tried to push through Staff 1 and Staff 2 to attempt
to physically assault Youth A. Youth B then tried to get into
Youth A’s bedroom, but the door was closed. Youth B was
able to calm down and reported to Staff 1 that she
destroyed Youth A’s Bath and Body Works items in her
bathroom. This information was reported to Supervisor.
- Facility Client Handbook- This handbook is provided to
youth at the facility. Within the guidelines section it notes
that, “all personal valuables are your responsibility. You
may ask the staff to secure any small valuable items in safe
or give to your Case Worker.”
- Facility Protecting Client Property Policy recently
reviewed on March 2015- This policy notes that personal
belongings and valuables of clients placed in residential
care of great significance to them and are to be treated with
great care and respect. Based on the program a youth can
have their own possessions of valuables in their room
which they are responsible for.
- Facility Behavior Management Policy recently reviewed
on December 2024- This policy noted staff are to use non-
physical intervention skills, such as verbal de-escalation,
5

medication conflict resolution, active listening, and verbal
and observational methods to prevent emergency safety
situations. Staff are also trained on Crisis Prevention
Institute (CPI) training which is ongoing training annually.
This policy notes all youth will have a Youth Behavior
Management Risk Assessment/Safety Plan completed by
the Intake Department Staff upon admission which is also
provided to staff to help support the youth. Staff are also
trained on De-escalation, Voluntary Time Out (VTO),
Segregation for Safety, Therapeutic De-escalation, Escort
and Physical Intervention (CPI) to help support the youth’s
behaviors. Voluntary Time Out is noted when a youth
voluntary requests removal from a stressful situation in
order to utilize their coping strategies. Segregation For
Safety is when one youth is having increased behaviors
and staff is in charge of getting the other youth out of the
area so they are not exposed to the behaviors.
- Youth A inventory received- This inventory form was
completed showing the items had been replaced for Youth
A’s personal items.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as it was shown in the video
that staff made sure the doors were closed during the time Youth
B was escalated. It was reported Youth B at some period of time
did destroy Youth A’s bathroom products but was noted to be
replaced. These items were also viewed to be replaced within
Youth A’s bathroom during a walkthrough of the building on May
2, 2025.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
